intro: Circaea lutetiana f. quadrisulcata, commonly known as the four-ribbed wood sorrel, is a herbaceous perennial plant characterized by its trifoliate leaves with four distinct longitudinal veins. It belongs to the family Primulaceae and is native to temperate regions of Europe. The plant typically grows in moist, shaded environments such as woodlands and stream banks. Its flowers are small, white or pale pink, and are arranged in cymes, often blooming in late spring. The subspecies is distinguished by its unique leaf venation pattern, which gives it its specific epithet "quadrisulcata."
